comments.text: I had steak last night and tonight,  only because I'm trying to reduce portion sizes and it was big enough to cut in half. I slso didn't want to freeze it. Served it with a  garlic mushroom and cream sauce, with white wine and thyme, and a baked potato. It was lovely.

comments.text: Good luck with child. You are going to make a perfect mum.  XX
comments.author: @JefJones-v2n

comments.text:
1) Gotta rest on a solid surface so the steak can reabsorb the juices (that it lost in the first half) during the second half! Putting it on a surface with holes just means lost juices! Sure you 'can' use them in a pan sauce, but that's just adding them to the surface again and they're so much better inside!
2) I personally prefer a dryer steak, in the Devonshire pub style - first salt the steak and leave to sit for an hour or two.
Then brush off the salt (enough has absorbed that you don't need it visible on the surface) and pat it very dry with a towel.
Then straight in a hot pan. No oil, no butter, no basting! Just straight-out steak! (Cooked using the timings mentioned here - a minute on each side going upwards for each level of doneness; so 1min each side for rare, 2min for medium rare, 3min for medium, 4min for medium done, 5min for well done.)
Because it's so dry, you get an even better sear, and sometimes even a little bit of a flaky 'char' if the pan is hot enough (even without direct fire). And a perfectly juicy interior too!
comments.author: @TheFallowCartouche
